item.title: Missiles Fired at Kyiv as African Delegation Visits
item.description: Explosions sounded in the Ukrainian capital as top African leaders visited the city on what they have billed as a peace initiative.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned house in the Ukrainian village of Blahodatne, on Thursday.

item.title: Rescued From a Flooded Island Behind Russian Lines in Ukraine
item.description: To many, the destruction of a dam on the Dnipro River in Ukraine brought devastation. To some stranded in Russian-occupied territory, it brought freedom.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Maria Varenikova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kateryna Krupych, holding her daughter Maria, 4, after they were rescued.

item.title: As Blinken Heads to China, Suspicion Awaits Him
item.description: Even as Beijing prepares for a visit by the secretary of state, China’s leader has made clear his expectations of more hostile superpower competition.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will begin his visit to China on Sunday.

item.title: Pope Francis Leaves Rome Hospital and Returns to Vatican After Surgery
item.description: Doctors have advised the 86-year-old pontiff to take it easy after undergoing treatment to deal with a hernia that caused painful intestinal blockages.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis was discharged from the Policlinico A. Gemelli hospital in Rome on Friday.

item.title: Tunisians Mourn a Hard-Fought Freedom Rapidly Slipping Away
item.description: When reflecting on their Arab Spring revolution, Tunisians often say that freedom of expression was the only concrete achievement. As the country slides back toward autocracy, that, too, is being quickly eroded.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hajer Tlili, in green, joined Mosaïque FM a year before Tunisia’s revolution. In its aftermath, she became a star political host.

item.title: Retaking Villages Leaves Ukrainian Troops Exposed and Diving for Cover
item.description: The Ukrainian counteroffensive has enjoyed some early successes, but with every step forward, the soldiers are increasingly exposed to Russian firepower.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Trump and Johnson Were Accused of Breaking Rules. One Lost Party Support.
item.description: Donald J. Trump and Boris Johnson are at the heart of political tempests at home, facing different accusations and far different results.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson on his morning run on Thursday. Mr. Johnson abruptly resigned last week after a committee of lawmakers found he had deliberately misled them about violating pandemic lockdown rules.

item.title: Greece Detains 9 Amid Search for Migrants After Crowded Ship Capsizes
item.description: The authorities revised the toll of the deadly shipwreck down to 78. But hundreds of people were feared missing, and nine survivors were detained on criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Workers transporting body bags from a Coast Guard ship to the port of Kalamata, Greece, on Thursday.

item.title: In Darfur, Sudan, Brutal Killing of Governor Heralds New Round of Violence
item.description: The United Nations blamed Sudanese paramilitaries for the death of the governor of West Darfur, Khamis Abdullah Abakar. Sudan’s war has destabilized a fragile western region devastated by genocide in the early 2000s.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Sudan News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An undated photograph released by Sudanese state media showing the West Darfur governor, Khamis Abdullah Abakar.

item.title: Russia-China Bond Is Closely Watched, and Fraught
item.description: The shows of bonhomie between the two leaders reflect the bond between Russia and China, which could become more fraught as Russian dependence deepens.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin during a dinner at the Kremlin in Moscow in March.

item.title: Indian Politician and Ex-Wrestling Chief Charged With Sexual Harassment
item.description: The charges against Brij Bhushan Sharan Singh, follow months of protest by prominent female wrestlers, who complained that the authorities had turned a deaf ear to their allegations.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Brij Bhushan Sharan Singh, a politician and former head of India’s wrestling federation, in Gonda, India, in January.

item.title: Kenyan Cult Survivors, Still Refusing to Eat, Face Suicide Charges
item.description: Dozens of members rescued from a church whose pastor is accused of telling followers to starve themselves appeared in court. A judge sent them to rehab rather than jail to await another hearing.
item.dc:creator: Mohamed Ahmed and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The mass gravesite in the Shakahola Forest in Kenya in April. As of this week, 318 bodies have been exhumed.

item.title: North Korea Fires 2 Ballistic Missiles
item.description: The launch of the short-range projectiles came the same day the United States and South Korean militaries conducted a joint live-fire drill.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television in a railway station in Seoul on Thursday showed file footage of a previous North Korean missile launch during the announcement of a new launch.

item.title: Canada Highway Crash: At Least 15 Killed in Manitoba Collision
item.description: A bus and a semitruck collided on a rural stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway in Manitoba on Thursday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The aftermath of the crash near Carberry, Manitoba, on Thursday.

item.title: Donald Trump Has a Polling Problem
item.description: Most Republicans still support Trump. But the polls still suggest the federal indictment is hurting him.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Donald Trump’s rallied outside Mar-a-Lago after Trump appeared in a New York courtroom in April.

item.title: Japan Changes Its Rape Laws to Require Consent
item.description: Japan’s previous laws on sexual assault did not mention permission and required that the crime include physical force. The new law also raises the age of consent to 16, from 13.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Japan’s Upper House of Parliament unanimously approved changes to the country’s sex crime laws on Friday.

item.title: He Ran Sudan’s Iconic Acropole Hotel. Then He Had to Flee Khartoum.
item.description: Thanasis Pagoulatos led the family business, Khartoum’s oldest inn, through decades of tumult. Sudan’s latest breakdown proved too much.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thanasis Pagoulatos, whose family built up the historic Acropole Hotel in Khartoum, was forced to evacuate Sudan in April.

item.title: Australia’s Opportunities and Challenges on the Path to ‘Net Zero’
item.description: Shipping sunshine? Alan Finkel’s take on the nation’s possible future as a leader in clean energy.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Giacomo d'Orlando for The New York Times
item.media:description: A solar hub in Christmas Creek, Australia.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s counteroffensive presses on.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s 68th Brigade resting outside of the village of Blahodatne, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Counteroffensive Is Grueling and Costly but Promising, U.S. Says
item.description: American and Ukrainian defense officials said the fight to dislodge dug-in Russian forces occupying southeastern Ukraine was expected to be brutal.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s 68th Brigade resting inside a destroyed and abandoned building outside of the village of Blahodatne, Ukraine, on Thursday. The village was retaken from Russian forces in ongoing Ukrainian counteroffensive operations.

item.title: Irma Capece Minutolo, Opera Singer and Partner to Exiled King, Dies at 87
item.description: The former Naples beauty queen became famous as the companion to the playboy Farouk I of Egypt, then carved out a successful opera career.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Russian Antiwar Activist Dies in Prison After Claiming He Had Been Tortured
item.description: Anatoly Berezikov is believed to be the first person in Russia to die in police custody after being jailed for opposing the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oleg Matsnev
item.media:description: A building adorned with the letter Z, a symbol of support for Russian military action in Ukraine, in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, where Anatoly Berezikov was jailed.

item.title: Pope Francis Will Leave Hospital on Friday, Vatican Says
item.description: The Vatican described the pope’s recovery nine days after undergoing abdominal surgery as “regular.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis during a general audience in St. Peter’s Square this month.

item.title: Glenda Jackson, Oscar-Winning Actress Turned Politician, Dies at 87
item.description: She walked away from a successful acting career to enter the British Parliament, before returning to the stage as the title character in an acclaimed “King Lear.”
item.dc:creator: Benedict Nightingale

item.title: Trump and the Fun Factor
item.description: How his legal challenges play into his reputation as an entertainer.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Former President Donald Trump appeared at a campaign event at his Bedminister Golf Club in New Jersey, after arriving directly from his arraignment in Miami.

item.title: IAEA Chief Arrives at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant to Assess Safety
item.description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the head of the United Nations’ atomic agency, is investigating conditions at the plant, which is held by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Receding water levels along the banks of the Dnipro River have raised alarms about the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, occupied by Russian forces, seen in the background.

item.title: Election Probe in Thailand Targets Pita Limjaroenrat
item.description: Activists say the case against the candidate, Pita Limjaroenrat, is part of a broader effort to nullify election results and further erode democracy in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, center, announcing the formation of a progressive coalition in Thailand in May.

item.title: TikTok, Shein and Other Companies Distance Themselves From China
item.description: Companies are moving headquarters and factories outside the country and cleaving off their Chinese businesses. It’s not clear the strategy will work.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Cooper Neill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers at a Shein pop-up in Plano, Texas, last year. Shein is among the Chinese companies taking steps to distance themselves from their home country.

item.title: Boris Johnson Misled Parliament Over Covid Lockdown Parties, Report Says
item.description: The report offered a damning verdict on Boris Johnson, the former British prime minister, who quit Parliament last week.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving his home in London in March.

item.title: NATO Defense Chiefs Vow to Stand by Ukraine
item.description: U.S. officials urge patience, describing a long, bloody, difficult fight.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian 35th Marine Brigade at a mortar position in the area of Avdiivka, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, firing on Russian positions in May.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: U.S. nuclear negotiations with Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Iranian Supreme Leader Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the Iranian supreme leader.

item.title: Key Environmentalists Back Biden, Despite Broken Oil Promises
item.description: Four major environmental groups are endorsing President Biden’s re-election bid, but some climate activists say his approval of drilling projects has been a betrayal.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Environmental activists rallied outside the White House on a rainy Earth Day in April.

item.title: Hoping to Avert Nuclear Crisis, U.S. Seeks Informal Agreement With Iran
item.description: The talks reflect a resumption of diplomacy between the United States and Iran after the collapse of negotiations to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a photograph released by state news. He said that he could endorse a deal with the United States if Iran’s nuclear infrastructure is kept intact.

item.title: Man Who Questioned Gender of Girl, 9, Spurs Outrage
item.description: A track and field event in British Columbia has engendered debate about transphobia in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: A track and field meet for elementary students held last week in Kelowna, British Columbia, where a man questioned a 9-year-old girl’s gender.

item.title: NATO Sees No Change in Russia’s Nuclear Posture After Lukashenko’s Claims
item.description: The move described by the leader of Belarus would be another sign of worsening relations between Moscow and the West.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus in Sochi, Russia, last week.

item.title: Germany Adopts a National Security Plan. Critics Call It ‘Weak.’
item.description: The country’s first national security strategy is an attempt to set priorities, especially since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but hard commitments were short in supply.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, center, along with members of his cabinet, introduced the country’s first comprehensive national security strategy on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Crisis Enters New Phase After Move by Netanyahu
item.description: A bitter dispute over a planned judicial overhaul had calmed as political leaders negotiated. But talks were postponed on Wednesday, after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu moved to disrupt a vote.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the Knesset on Wednesday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Accuses Rishi Sunak of Blocking House of Lords Nominations
item.description: The former prime minister tried to elevate some lawmakers, as British leaders do when they leave office. But three didn’t make the cut, and now he’s fighting with Rishi Sunak.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was “rubbish” that he had lobbied Rishi Sunak to overturn the way nominees to the House of Lords were vetted and approved.

item.title: U.S. Support for Ukraine Aid Starts to Fray After Debt Limit Deal
item.description: Spending caps set by the debt limit bill have empowered critics of U.S. aid to Ukraine, threatening the bipartisan coalition that has kept military assistance flowing to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: The 3rd Separate Assault Brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine at the front line South of Bakhmut on Friday.

item.title: Cyclone Biparjoy: India’s Death Toll Climbs to 5
item.description: A father and son were killed after being swept away by floodwaters, the authorities said. The storm weakened to the equivalent of a tropical storm after making landfall as a cyclone.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir, Judson Jones, Zia ur-Rehman and Claire Moses

item.title: Droves of Imran Khan’s Allies Defect as Military Ramps Up Crackdown
item.description: More than 100 key allies of Mr. Khan have left his party in recent weeks as Pakistan’s military tries to sideline the former leader.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan, center, leaving after appearing in a court, in Lahore, Pakistan, last week.

item.title: Blinken Plans to Meet With Top Chinese Officials in Beijing
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, who leaves Friday, could meet with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, during a visit he had postponed because of a Chinese spy balloon.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trip is one that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken had to reschedule after canceling a planned visit in February, when a Chinese spy balloon flying over the United States caused an uproar.

item.title: The U.S. Is Paying Billions to Russia’s Nuclear Agency. Here’s Why.
item.description: Nuclear power companies rely on cheap enriched uranium made in Russia. That geopolitical dilemma is intensifying as climate change underscores the need for emissions-free energy.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Brian Kaiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uranium enrichment centrifuges at the ready in Ohio.

item.title: The UK’s Phillip Schofield Scandal Explained, From TV to Parliament
item.description: The resignation of a television anchor, followed by an admission of an affair with a younger colleague, has gripped the British media for weeks. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Phillip Schofield was one of the most prominent hosts on Britain’s biggest ad-supported television network.

item.title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive: What to Know
item.description: The Ukrainians are now on the offense. But measuring their progress is difficult this early on.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donetsk region set up a rocket launcher last week.

item.title: Berlusconi’s Legacy Lives On Beyond Italy’s Borders
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi rose when political parties were weakened and carried on through a cascade of scandals. Leaders like Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro have had similar trajectories.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A farewell to the former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi projected on a civic building in Genoa on Monday night.

item.title: Russia Sends Navalny Associates to Prison for “Extremism”
item.description: Lilia Chanysheva and Rustem Mulyukov are the first of the jailed opposition leader’s organization to be convicted of charges related to national security since the Russian government declared his group an “extremist organization.”
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Lilia Chanysheva during a court hearing in Ufa, Russia, on Wednesday.

item.title: China, Hosting Mahmoud Abbas, Pushes Mediator Role With Israel
item.description: In meeting with the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, Xi Jinping is pushing Beijing as an alternative to the U.S. for diplomatic leadership.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, welcoming Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, in Beijing. The visit is planned to last four days.

item.title: Israel Will Not Charge Soldiers Over Palestinian American Who Died
item.description: Omar Assad, 78, was found dead after being held at a building site last year by the Israeli Army. The military said the soldiers involved will be punished but not charged.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the body of Omar Assad during his funeral in the West Bank village of Jiljilya in 2022.

item.title: At Least 79 Die as Boat Carrying Migrants Sinks Near Greece
item.description: The disaster is the deadliest such episode off the country’s shores since the 2015 migrant crisis, and there were fears that the toll would rise. The cause was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Hellenic Coastguard, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: When Should a Former President Be Charged
item.description: What if Donald Trump were someone else?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Donald Trump arriving in New Jersey yesterday.

item.title: Germany Introduces Its First National Security Strategy
item.description: The war in Ukraine has heightened Germany’s sense that it has become vulnerable to new threats, but some critics said the strategy lacks detail.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany at the European Parliament in May.

item.title: Tensions Rise Over Big Oil’s Role at COP28 Climate Talks
item.description: The hosts of the United Nations global climate summit later this year aim to give fossil fuel companies a bigger voice, despite loud objections.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: Sultan al-Jaber leads the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company as well as the COP28 climate talks coming this November.

item.title: Inside the Minds of Some Russian Soldiers
item.description: At a bar in a once-occupied Ukrainian village, dehumanizing messages on the walls were a stark reminder that the Kremlin wants to stamp out Ukraine and its culture.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Gaelle Girbes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of the graffiti left in the bar in the village of Velyka Komyshuvakha, Ukraine, dehumanized Ukrainians, a grim staple of warfare.

item.title: Prison Sentence for José Rubén Zamora, Guatemalan Newspaper Publisher
item.description: The trial of José Rubén Zamora, the founder of a newspaper who was convicted of money laundering and sentenced to up to six years, came as critics say democracy in Guatemala is crumbling.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jody García
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Rubén Zamora, the founder and publisher of elPeriódico, a leading Guatemala newspaper, has denied any wrongdoing and has vowed to appeal.

item.title: How South Korean Food Waste Is Turned Into Feed, Fuel or Fertilizer
item.description: When wasted food rots in landfills, it pollutes soil and water — and warms the planet. Here’s how one country keeps that from happening.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
